reviewText:
12 Labours of Hercules is the best Time Management game I've ever played.  The extremely tight tuning, flexibility of play and excellent presentation makes the game incredibly fun and rewarding, especially for those who aim for perfection.

As with other titles in the genre, you're tasked with completing a set of goals in order to proceed to the next level.  While the goals vary, the general concept is the same; collect resources and construct buildings to beat the timer.  Efficiently managing your workers is at the heart of the gameplay, although it's by no means necessary if you want to play more casually, but doing so adds strategic depth to what is in essence a very simple game.  Ultimately, the more effort you put into challenging yourself, the more reward you'll get out of it.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=458157857
There are multiple ways to complete each level, but to earn gold, especially on Expert, not only are your multi-tasking skills put to the test but strategic planning as well.  Figuring out which routes need to be cleared first, the order buildings are to be constructed (and whether to level them fully or at all), and which of the multiple power-ups are most beneficial to reaching your goal is what makes the game so  fulfilling.  You can tear your hair out spending dozens of tries on a single level, but when you make that one small change that brings your +5 second run to a -5, the feeling of accomplishment is like nothing else.

A handful of mini-boss levels breaks up the standard gameplay with Hercules fighting off mythical beasts and smashing through barriers on his quest to save Megara.  These are enjoyable little interludes that add variety and humor to an already fun game.

Presentation is great as well.  I generally don't expect much graphically from these games, but the artwork is cute and the animations fun.  Musically, the soundtrack is a joy featuring plenty of classically inspired themes that are quite impressive for a casual title.  Topping it off is full Steam integration with achievements, cards, cloud saves, and even leader boards, something ALL casual games benefit from on the platform.

It's not often that I walk away from a game with not a single complaint, but 12 Labours of Hercules has managed that feat.  My only worry is that I will now hold all future Time Management games to the excellent standard of this gem, and that's a high precedent to reach. But excellence always comes at a price. Unless you absolutely abhor the genre, there's no excuse not owning this gem, especially considering the very generous sales it often receives.

Bottom Line: A must have gem that belongs in every gamer's library.

reviewText:
12 Labours of Hercules is a fun little resource and time management game by Jetdogs Studios which was designed for iOS and ported into PC due to its popularity later on. This first one in the series is fun, relaxing and a point on choice for a couple of easy achievements as the rest of the series. If you feel like sparing time for a series of automated actions to meet certain challenges and have a smile now and then, keep reading.

First and foremost, these games are vaguely based on the actual 12 Labours of Hercules, an epic poem written by Peisander in 600 BC, narrating the 12 years that legendary Greek hero spent in service to King Eurystheus to atone for killing his own family whence he was maddened by Hera. As you can see, these kiddy versions of the legend are not as gruesome as the actual tale. For the content of the game, there is little to no story. All we know is that Hades abducted Megara - Hercules' wife - for unknown reasons and we are to take her back by building a path between Hellas and the Underworld with the aid of our servants and some monster buddies of ours. The game - as the rest of its instalments - mostly consists of thrown around mythological figures and a most required happy ending.

As for the display, art is cartoonish and enjoyable; not the worst that I've encountered in these kind of casual games. Icons and animations are cute. Everything’s pretty much Disney-ish actually. Music is cute, but with this amount of repetition in each and every level you may prefer muting it down after some time.

As for the gameplay, you basically drive some servants to collect resources, build paths and activate certain encounters within a limited time while you and your monster 'buddies' overcome some challenges. Game mechanics are real simple and easy to master, and your abilities to buff certain conditions makes this a casual game with little strategic planning. The most you'd find to be challenging is the achievement to complete all levels on Gold Time. It is possible to finish all quests within 3-4 hours anyhow.

If you feel like taking a break from some serious business that you've been attending, this is the perfect game with little to no brain involvement. You mostly play it with your reaction rate. All these games do go for a decent sale most of the time, so you may prefer getting it in one of those times. Enjoy!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

After all these centuries, we have the truth behind this great hero of the Greek mythology. . . Ladies and Gents, Hercules always enjoy a snooze lying on his favourite red hammock! But we were never told of his faithful servants who helped him to achieve greatness.

“12 labours of Hercules” is an enjoyable casual / strategy game which offers you 50 levels to complete in a specific amount of time to get a “Golden Time”.

It will take 1:30 minutes to regenerate the item after you took it. Every order given to your servants needs foods, supplies and coins to be executed.

Further into the game, you will be able to use bonus powers that will make your servants run, build, regenerate supplies faster or even stop the clock for a while.

In regards to our extraordinary energetic Hercules, he will remove boulders, open gates, build temples, etc.  And yes, you will encounter minotaur’s, ghosts and other villains!!

reviewText:
The running joke in The 12 Labours of Hercules is that Our Mighty Hero only rarely rouses himself to do any actual labour - his trusty servants (ahem, slaves) race about at your command cutting down trees, clearing roads, filling in pits, picking up resources, building bridges, and erecting supply centers. Except when there's a star-powered Hero Task to do, Hercules spends levels resting happily in his hammock.

In each of this game's 40 levels you basically need to get across the map. That may involve clearing obstacles in the road; building bridges over rivers or ravines, or boats to sail away on; collecting gold for the trip; or disposing of monsters in your way. You'll gather riches (food, lumber, gold) to pay for everything you do, and generally there's just enough potential wealth in each map to make it to the end in time. Level design is attentive without being mean, and each level will run to solution in five to ten minutes, making this a perfect bite-sized casual game for I-have-a-few-minutes timing needs.

One clever and irritating design choice adds weight to game achievements by way of in-game monuments. Completing each level in Gold time (there are 10 levels per stage, four stages in all) builds a section of four acient artifacts that have nothing to do with anything, but sit there accusingly when they are only partially completed. In one stage, for example, you're building the Argo, and how can you not finish the Argo? It appeals to fundamental tinkering instincts, and makes the game hard (for me, at least) to complete casually. Because, you know, we've got to finish the Argo before we move on. Right?

Whether you breeze through 12 Labours, or dump hours and hours of just-one-more-try time into the durn thing - I'm at over 60 hours on Steam at this point - depends on two things: whether you are the sort of person who can peacefully leave your ancient wonders half-built, and whether you choose to play on Expert in the initial settings. Think carefully about this. The game is great pleasant fun, and making some of your Gold times on the Expert setting is HARD. With its little dollops of timed frustration, The 12 Labours of Hercules managed to fill up my scattered free time much more than I ever intended. You've been warned.

Once you finish this game, of course, parts II, III, and IV await. You've been warned, again.

There are other installments from this series: The Cretan Bull, Girl Power and Mother Nature. There are two modes, relaxed and expert, two difference between them is the timer speed and scoring. In relaxed mode, the timer drains at a slower rate and the scoring is low. In expert mode, the timer drain quicker and the scoring is much higher.

The stars that are earned from completing the level depends upon on how much time is left on the timer.

Three Gold star is when the time has not gone pass the arrow. Two Silver star is when the time has gone pass the arrow. One Bronze star is when the timer is completely empty.

Replaying any of the levels will improve the game score and the amount star.

There are few special bonuses: Freeze Time, Worker Movement/Work Speed, Additional Worker and Increases Resources. All of these special bonuses has a certain time limit but they can be used again once the bar fills-up. These special bonuses are very useful when the game is being played on expert mode.

I don't think that this game much of replay value to it. If you're into time management games then you might find this game somewhat enjoyable to certain extent.

A nice little game, easy enough to 100% (took me 5.5 hours and it can definitely be done faster than that) plus you can make a few cents of money by buying it on discount and selling the cards. But let's talk about the game itself.

The art style is alright, it has this cheery cartoonish style typical of casual games and/or mobile ports. A new level can often look really overwhelming because there's stuff EVERYWHERE so it can take a while to even realise where the objectives are and how you should reach them. The timer doesn't start until you click for the first time though so you can plan things out if you like.

The music is catchy, if a bit repetitive. But seeing as you can finish the whole thing in 5 hours or so, that's not a huge deal. The voice acting in the cutscenes made my brain hurt though, the guy was trying WAY too hard to sound intense.

As for the gameplay, it's really easy (possibly because I played on the lower difficulty setting) most of the time - what you need to do is just click everything that's clickable at the moment and you're likely to get gold time even without thinking about anything. Some levels do require some strategy (i.e. deciding what to spend your resources on first) and you can even lose a few of them (by 'lose' I mean 'reach a state in which they can't be finished'), but the difficulty remains quite forgiving until the very end. Just keep clicking. Which is exactly as repetitive as it sounds.
The minigames are a joke, by far the easiest part of the game.

So yeah, if you feel like you have just a few too many hours of time on your hands and want a casual game that won't require you to use your brain too much, this could be the thing for you.

reviewText:
Short version: 81%Good and simple mechanics, balanced yet challenging difficulty, decent length… this is what anyone would want from an indie title. It is a bit interesting to see no plot from something based on mythology, but ‘12 Labours of Hercules’ is still a good game for its genre.

Long version:12 Labours of Hercules is the first instalment in a fairly successful line of time management games that are supposed to be based on the mythical jobs of Heracles, the famous Hellenic hero. I say “supposed to”, because none of the games have actual stories, the myth is used as a visual theme only.

The mechanics are fairly simple: you gather three types of resources with your servants in order to remove a set of obstacles. When the road clears, you gather more resources, ad infinitum, until you finally reach the end of the path. For some added variety, sometimes you need the help of Hercules himself or one of his mythological buddies.

As for most time management games, the difficulty balances on a very narrow ledge. It is rather easy to pass a level within the basic time limit, but reaching the more constrained goal can be– pardon the pun– a Herculean task. Be ready to constantly retry several levels until you learn the only working sequence. On the plus side, this easily boosts an average play time of 2-3 hours into well over 6-8 hours.

reviewText:
12 Labours of Hercules has been one of the best casual time management games that I have ever played. You're tasked with the mission to save Megara, Hercules wife, and in order to do that you require the help of various servants to pave the way to victory. You'll realise how lazy Hercules actually is as his servants repair broken roads, haul stones and wood, cheese, and coins, back to Hercules' base. While it does not offer a true-to-text overview on Hercules, it provides a decent enough story.

Pros+  Achievements easily obtainable
+  Pegasus; what more could you ask for?
+  Tight gameplay: very responsive to your commands
+  All important information is laid out in a neat UI format
+  Offers enough at its small asking price (more on this later)
+  Very generous graphics: for a cheap game, the quality is simply amazing
+  Requires strategy while also remembering the casual nature of the game
+  Levels are doable; you can choose the gameplay difficulty (casual all the way to hard I believe)
+  You can get it at a dirt cheap price: in my case, I bought it at around .99$, but I've seen the price as low as .29$

Neutral±  This was my first time management game, so I didn't know what to expect. I couldn't play it all at once and sometimes it felt like it dragged (repetitive nature of the genre)

Cons-  Little to offer in terms of music: quite repetitive but doesn't detract from the game quality itself

With a lot of companies now copying Jetdog Studios time management games, you would be doing yourself a favour by trying out the original.

What this game deserves in my books:
9/10

A set of four equally nice, neatly made (in every aspect) time managers. Slightly diversified (with new game play features, bonuses and surprises) to make each game a bit different, while keeping enough in common with the previouse one(s), which shortens waste of time and nerve on mastering the next game, that's valuable. Taken into account the fact that games like these are not my idea of fun (or they weren't at least))) - what better recommendation could i give to a game. If you are looking for a highly involving and entertaining, not all that hard yet challenging enough game - check this one. Probably you will be pleased even beyond your expectations.

Полностью прошел все четыре на экспертной сложности и не отказался бы от пятой. С учетом того, что сами игры далеко не из списка моих предпочтений (по крайней мере не были))), вряд ли я придумаю способ высказаться об игре в еще более позитивном духе.
В общем, если вы подыскиваете что-нибудь достаточно увлекательно-развлекательное, при этом не слишком сложное, но тем не менее бросающее определенный вызов вашим способностям в пределах разумных затрат времени и сил - то это как раз то что надо. Вполне возможно порадует даже сверх ожиданий.

Its the first time I've ever been paid by a developer to play their game. Serious! Dead Set!

I bought the game for 14 cents and sold the badges for 15 cents. That's a 1 cent profit.

Having said that I have spent 8 hrs on the game for my 1 cent profit. Think I need to get another more higher paying job.

12 labours of Hercules is done by these people http://jetdogs.com/projects/  and the game ofcourse is very loosely based on the Greek Myth of Hercules the greatest of heroes who after becoming mad and murdering his wife and sons goes off to find some sort of penance for his actions by performing 12 incredible labours. In the game it states that he does it in order to bring his wife back from hades, but in the real myth side of things it is simply only for penance for himself.

Check out the wikipedia if your interested in the real story... https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labours_of_Hercules

Having said that it's quite creepy to see how much Hercules is smiling in the game knowing he has just killed everyone he ever loved. Seriously... his smile is so big from ear to ear that your kind of amazed that half his head doesn't just lift straight off. Sort of like the smile you would have on your face when you've just had one of those heavenly bowel movements in the toilet, thanking the dear Lord the ordeal has just passed.

The game is a time/resource management game. I haven't played many of these as I have had personally many bad experiences with these types of games on Facebook. Normally on facebook the time criteria's are ridiculous and the powerups involve micro transactions. Here quite the opposite with the developer giving you 1 cents. The objective is to simply order his servants around to perform and manage different tasks so you can get to the overall goal in a gold timely manner. The tutorial explains everything nicely and will have you feeling at home in no time. Hercules most of the time just lounges around expecting people to fan him and drop grapes in his mouth like the true hero he is. Now that sounds like a good job. How do I get that one? Do I have to murder people to get that job? Having said all that, Hercules does do some work as he is the one which will be required to vanquish four bosses/mini games while intimidating them with his eternal grin which all garden gnomes would be in envy to imitate.

Over all the game is quite pleasant to play, fun and the art cartoons quite entertaining to the eye. Worth the 1 cent in your pocket when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
12 Labours of Hercules is a casual time-puzzle game. Hades has kidnapped Megara, and it is up to Hercules, and especially his servant, to travel ancient Greece to save her.

Pros: While Hercules is taking a nap, you order his servant around in single-screen puzzles, where you must reach your objectives within a set time limit. The point is to optimize the order in which you pick the resources and accomplish tasks that consumes those same resources, tasks such as fixing the path or upgrading buildings that generate resources or supply additional servants. As you progress, you will get access to a few bonus powers, and gather allies such as the Medusa, the Pegasus, the Cyclops and the Cerberus, each of which can defeat enemies blocking your path or accomplish special tasks. The colorful map is overlayed with symbols of the game achievements you accomplished, and landmarks that gets build as you get gold rating at each levels.

Cons: The game is extremely easy, you'll rarely ever need to restart a level to get gold rating. Due to lack of randomization, it's unlikely you'll ever replay any levels except for the slightly less easy-to-get achievements. The story really is an excuse to give the world a setting.

Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

This game is basic, even for a casual game, and might be a bit more challenging for a much younger audience. But keeping in mind its price, I'd recommend it for children and achievement hunters, but anyone seeking any form of challenge in a puzzle should stay clear.

reviewText: Straightforward time manager with in a Greek mythological antiquity setting.  You have workers for mundane tasks like collecting food, chopping woods, clearing paths, and have Hercules for bigger tasks like tossing boulders or buidling temples.  Each task either yields food, wood. etc., requires a certain amount of those resources, or is some combination, e.g., requiring food and wood to mine gold, which is another main resource.   The workers have to run back and forth to their little house which takes time, so the order in which you do the tasks matters.  Not only is distance the workers have to run a factor, but how quickly you can upgrade your house to get another worker, or build a farm to generate food periodically, can also have a big impact.\n\nAll in all a solid time manager that is reasonably priced at $3.  It is also available on iOS, but it is not clear whether this was a port to or from iOS since the release date (according to Metacritic) was Oct. 30, 2013 for PC, but April 23, 2014 for the iOS version.  Regardless, this game stands on its on as a PC game, while it certainly would make a good touch-based game, since you are mainly just clicking the next task for workers/Hercules to perform, the game has enough depth and variation to retain one's interest.

Sets in Ancient Greek, help Hercules break the way to rescue his wife from the evil Hades! This is the first time that JetDogs has developed a Time Management game, to be honest, they have done well.

If you are a hardcore Resource/Time Management player, you would feel like you have played this kind of game so many times. 12 Labours of Hercules is nothing out of the ordinary, with simple gameplay, simple quests and similar story. The visual design is very flat and the colors could have been much more colorful. Despite that, the graphics are very sharp and quite calm to look at.

12 Labours of Hercules is not a challenging game, most of the levels are pretty easy even when the difficulty keeps increasing. It is a great game fro beginners as all the objectives are clear, the controls are nice and you also do not need to wait for your workers to come back before assign them with new tasks.

The game does have all the features required for a good game of this kind though. It has voice-overs, relaxed mode you can choose to play as well as pretty exciting Boss Battles every 10 levels. We also like the Achievements this game featured, it has some standard ones as well as some unique ones that require some work to achieve.

12 Labours of Hercules is based on a simple gameplay and plain designs with a couple of innovative aspects. Although it does not offer any challenges, it is a good, fun, relaxing game for those who are new to the genre.

reviewText:
What a charming game!
5.7 hours and I've finished the game on casual difficulty

I don't know why they call this the 12 labours of Hercules, as he is napping in a hammock most of the time. Your servants are the real heroes in this game. Extremely simple concept with only one mouse button required.

The game is split into 4 chapters, as Hercules chases the man who kidnapped his wife. You have a global map where each level is displayed. The game is linear--you can only go one way to get to the end. You must complete each mission in order.

A typical game:
Once you select the mission, you begin with typically one servant and a napping Hercules. You must complete the objectives, such as collect a feather, and collect 80 gold. The mechanics are simple--issue a servant to complete a task, such as chop a tree down and bring back the lumber. The servant will do it provided you have enough of the resources required.

This is why it's a game and not a bore: Time and Resource Management. You decide what your laborers do. The idea is to plot out a strategy in which all your workers will be performing operating in harmony. For example, sometimes it will cost food to chop a tree to get lumber. You predict this and already have another worker getting the food to make up for the loss. There is a time limit, and the faster you complete the mission, the better your score. The missions can be completed any way you choose, even if you are terrible at resource management, you will find a way to complete the mission.

The game has two difficulties, casual--which I have just completed, and expert (which I will definitely be doing). For $0.29 on sale, you get trading cards worth approximately the same amount. You likely won't profit by playing this game, but if you sell the cards, you may just get it for free!

I've been putting off buying the games in this series, as I didn't know if I'd like the style, but I'm finally glad I tried it, as I know I'll enjoy the others in the series!

Short, satisfying, colourful, and it's something different. Go buy it.

TLDR first - in 12 Labours of Hercules, there's a very thin line between a very challenging and interesting game and utter boredom and aimlessness. This line is choosing your difficulty and challenges wisely.

12LoH is a time management game, where you collect a few types of resources (basically food, wood and gold), and with this, construct structures, enlist the help of mythical creatures and solve specific objectives. Presentation is flawless, as it looks pleasing to the eye, the sound and music are decent, and the controls are simple and intuitive. Level design is either superb or totally irrelevant - see difficulty again.

So why the duality? In a game like this, challenges can come from two sources: figuring out how to solve the levels, and solving the levels within a limited amount of time. 12LoH simply omits the first - most levels can be solved by arbitrary clicking on the screen, it's not easy to create a situation where you can't go on. As there's no challenge, walking through the game easily loses its appeal after 3 or 4 levels. So it's up to the time constraints to make the game interesting - however, you automatically get bronze for walking through. For silver, you need to finish within the par time. This is also very easy - even on expert difficulty, you'll either do it on first try, or, if you walk into a couple of traps, you'll avoid them on the second playthrough and easily get the silver medal. No challenge here, either.

What about gold? Every level has a gold time constraint, and if you're going for that, the game suddenly comes alive! All of a sudden, you need to appraise the level's paths, judge resource requirements for the final outcome, and continuously forecast a few steps ahead to make sure your people keep moving. If they don't, then bye-bye gold medal. With the gold constraint, the levels are very good and often quite wicked. With the gold constraint, the game offers a lot of challenge. With the gold constraint, it's very much recommended, as it's tremendous fun.

Thinking about whether this game deserves a positive review or not is pretty hard. Ultimately, it can be cheap, but also can be surprisingly fun enough at times that I believe it's worth a try if you enjoy time management games.

Like I stated, Twelve Labours of Hercules is a fairly simple time management game where you have to reach an objective, which can change between levels. There are enough different gameplay elements added in to keep you coming back, with different bonuses available for use and others. At the end of each 10 stages, you get to play a minigame, which I'll get back to later. The game lacks a clear storyline, making you wonder why you're trying reach some artifact or find Prometheus when your real goal is to save your wife. However, this game is also very easy, and it didn't take very long to fully complete the game, so don't expect a real challenge.

The main problem is that the production value can be very low at times. The drawn backgrounds look great, and the cutscenes aren't terrible either. The real failure here are the 3d graphics. They range from cheap to hilarious, and really bring down the game. Especially the minigames, which can look completely ridiculous. The sound effects for them are on the same level. Many different assets are reused frequently, and this is why the company's managed to make three more games in less than a year.

Anyways, if you want a casual, easy time management game, try this out, but expect some weirder moments. You can grab this for an absurdly cheap price on sale anyways, so why not?

A very cute resource game where you sent your slaves to collect food and materials to break down things to get more food and materials!

Story: Don't expect anything beyond Mario quality story, Peach, I mean Megara is kidnapped by Hades (Bowser) and you as Hercules (Mario) need to save her. The story is told in some little animate clips after each 10 levels. Narrating the story is a voice that sounds like it's trying to rhyme, or at least should be, and just has a lot of weird ways of saying things and comes off as improper english, but hey you're not playing this game for the story

Graphics: Cute little graphics, what you see in the screenshots is what you get. Visually pleasing but nothing 3D amazing

Overall/Gameplay: While the mechanics of get stuff to build stuff to get more stuff can get tedious there are achivements to get (pretty easily) and power ups to help along the way. I played in easy mode just because I wasn't sure how hard it would be and never had to redo a level to get the 3 Star Time and in some levels I clearly did not deserve the 3 stars but from the repitive nature of levels it can be best this way otherwise you might burn out on it too quickly. You can get all achivements no matter the difficulty so don't worry about having to play a super hard mode if you just want a casual pick up game you can pick up, get 100% in and drop. This game is perfect for killing some time and when it's on sale it's usually $.50 and the card drops pay for about 3/5ths the cost so a great little addition I can highly reccomend!

Everyone has this big pile of shame on steam: games you dont really know how and when you get, and aren't really into playing them. 3 days ago I decided to at least try to finish as many of them as I can. This was the first one.
I really had no idea what to expect - haven't even visited store page. So without high expectations, I gave it a go.
The easiest comparison is Farm Freenzy - here you have to help Hercules to complete his 12 labours. To do so, you assign tasks to servants, who collect resources (Food, Supples and Gold), remove obstacles frome the road and so on. There are special characters, like Medusa or Cerberus, used to remove special obstacles like harpies or ghosts. And there is Hercules, most of the time resting, mainly used to remove boulders. So yeah. Thats it for dramatis personae.
Game contains 4... well, lets call them chapters. Each of them has 9 regular maps and a minigame. In regular ones, you have to assign tasks to servants and heroes to complete objectives, like build farm (ah, there are buildings. They provide bonuses like additional supplies per ~15 seconds or increase amount of aviable servants), repel ghosts and so on. Minigames allow us to control Hercules, and give obiectives like shoot hydras' heads or click at the right ingredient, filling the time with shooting oncoming enemies. Nothing really hard. Well, i'm not a fan of hard games, yet this one provided no challenge.
There are more features, like bonuses (when bar reaches certain point, you can enable faster work, movement, more resources and so on), but making things short - this game is good. I mean for a game you wouldn't notice browsing Steam Store, but good. It's not game messiach, but it is enjoyable.
